section.heading: Short title.

content.p: This chapter may be cited as the Nevada Ethics in Government Law.

section.heading: Legislative findings and declarations.

content.p: It is hereby declared to be the public policy of this State that: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A public office is a public trust and shall be held for the sole benefit of the people. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A public officer or employee must commit himself or herself to avoid conflicts between the private interests of the public officer or employee and those of the general public whom the public officer or employee serves. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Legislature finds and declares that: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The increasing complexity of state and local government, more and more closely related to private life and enterprise, enlarges the potentiality for conflict of interests. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

To enhance the peopleï¿½s faith in the integrity and impartiality of public officers and employees, adequate guidelines are required to show the appropriate separation between the roles of persons who are both public servants and private citizens. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

In interpreting and applying the provisions of this chapter that are applicable to State Legislators, the Commission must give appropriate weight and proper deference to the public policy of this State under which State Legislators serve as ï¿½citizen Legislatorsï¿½ who have other occupations and business interests, who are expected to have particular philosophies and perspectives that are necessarily influenced by the life experiences of the Legislator, including, without limitation, professional, family and business experiences, and who are expected to contribute those philosophies and perspectives to the debate over issues with which the Legislature is confronted. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The provisions of this chapter do not, under any circumstances, allow the Commission to exercise jurisdiction or authority over or inquire into, intrude upon or interfere with the functions of a State Legislator that are protected by legislative privilege and immunity pursuant to the Constitution of the State of Nevada orNRS 41.071.

section.heading: Definitions.

content.p: As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise requires, the words and terms defined inNRS 281A.032to281A.170, inclusive, have the meanings ascribed to them in those sections.

section.heading: ï¿½Adjudicatory hearingï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Adjudicatory hearingï¿½ means a hearing held by the Commission pursuant toNRS 281A.745to receive evidence concerning an ethics complaint and render an opinion in the matter.

section.heading: ï¿½Advisory opinionï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Advisory opinionï¿½ means an advisory opinion rendered by the Commission pursuant toNRS 281A.670to281A.690, inclusive.

section.heading: ï¿½Agencyï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Agencyï¿½ means any state agency or local agency.

section.heading: ï¿½Business entityï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Business entityï¿½ means an organization or enterprise operated for economic gain, including, without limitation, a proprietorship, partnership, firm, business, company, trust, joint venture, syndicate, corporation or association.

section.heading: ï¿½Candidateï¿½ defined.

content.p: Whose name appears on an official ballot at any election.

section.heading: ï¿½Commissionï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Commissionï¿½ means the Commission on Ethics.

section.heading: ï¿½Commitment in a private capacityï¿½ defined.

content.p: Who is related to the public officer or employee, or to the spouse or domestic partner of the public officer or employee, by blood, adoption, marriage or domestic partnership within the third degree of consanguinity or affinity; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Who employs the public officer or employee, the spouse or domestic partner of the public officer or employee or a member of the household of the public officer or employee; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
With whom the public officer or employee has a substantial and continuing business relationship; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

With whom the public officer or employee has any other commitment, interest or relationship that is substantially similar to a commitment, interest or relationship described in subsections 1 to 5, inclusive.

section.heading: ï¿½Compensationï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Compensationï¿½ means any money, thing of value or economic benefit conferred on or received by any person in return for services rendered, personally or by another.

section.heading: ï¿½Decisionï¿½ defined.

content.p: The making of a ï¿½decisionï¿½ is the exercise of governmental power to adopt laws, regulations or standards, render quasi-judicial decisions, establish executive policy or determine questions involving substantial discretion. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The term does not include: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The functions of the judiciary. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The functions of a State Legislator that are protected by legislative privilege and immunity pursuant to the Constitution of the State of Nevada orNRS 41.071.

section.heading: ï¿½Declaration of candidacyï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Declaration of candidacyï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 293.0455.

section.heading: ï¿½Deferral agreementï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Deferral agreementï¿½ means an agreement entered into between the Executive Director and the subject of an ethics complaint pursuant toNRS 281A.740.

section.heading: ï¿½Domestic partnerï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Domestic partnerï¿½ means a person in a domestic partnership.

section.heading: ï¿½Domestic partnershipï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Domestic partnershipï¿½ means a domestic partnership as defined inNRS 122A.040.

section.heading: ï¿½Ethics complaintï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Ethics complaintï¿½ means a request for an opinion which is filed with the Commission or initiated by the Commission on its own motion pursuant toNRS 281A.710regarding the propriety of the conduct of a public officer or employee under the statutory ethical standards set forth in this chapter.

section.heading: ï¿½Executive Directorï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Executive Directorï¿½ means the Executive Director appointed by the Commission pursuant toNRS 281A.230.

section.heading: ï¿½Householdï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Householdï¿½ means an association of persons who live in the same home or dwelling and who are related by blood, adoption, marriage or domestic partnership.

section.heading: ï¿½Intentionallyï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Intentionallyï¿½ means voluntarily or deliberately, rather than accidentally or inadvertently. The term does not require proof of bad faith, ill will, evil intent or malice.

section.heading: ï¿½Knowinglyï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Knowinglyï¿½ imports a knowledge that the facts exist which constitute the act or omission, and does not require knowledge of the prohibition against the act or omission. Knowledge of any particular fact may be inferred from the knowledge of such other facts as should put an ordinarily prudent person upon inquiry.

section.heading: ï¿½Local agencyï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Local agencyï¿½ means any local legislative body, agency, bureau, board, commission, department, division, office or other unit of any county, city or other political subdivision.

section.heading: ï¿½Member of a local legislative bodyï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Member of a local legislative bodyï¿½ means a member of a board of county commissioners, a governing body of a city or a governing body of any other political subdivision who performs any function that involves introducing, voting upon or otherwise acting upon any matter of a permanent or general character which may reflect public policy.

section.heading: ï¿½Opinionï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Opinionï¿½ means an opinion rendered by the Commission in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The term includes, without limitation, the disposition of an ethics complaint by stipulation, agreed settlement, consent order or default as authorized byNRS 233B.121.

section.heading: ï¿½Pecuniary interestï¿½ defined.

content.p: Anything of economic value; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Payments or other money which a person is owed or otherwise entitled to by virtue of any statute, regulation, code, ordinance or contract or other agreement.

section.heading: ï¿½Political subdivisionï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Political subdivisionï¿½ means any county, city or other local government as defined inNRS 354.474.

section.heading: ï¿½Public employeeï¿½ defined.

content.p: Performs public duties under the direction and control of a public officer for compensation paid by the State or any county, city or other political subdivision; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is designated as a public employee for the purposes of this chapter pursuant toNRS 281A.182.

section.heading: ï¿½Public officerï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Public officerï¿½ means a person who is: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Elected or appointed to a position which: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Is established by the Constitution of the State of Nevada, a statute of this State or a charter or ordinance of any county, city or other political subdivision; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Involves the exercise of a public power, trust or duty; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Designated as a public officer for the purposes of this chapter pursuant toNRS 281A.182. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½the exercise of a public power, trust or dutyï¿½ means: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Actions taken in an official capacity which involve a substantial and material exercise of administrative discretion in the formulation of public policy; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The expenditure of public money; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The administration of laws and rules of the State or any county, city or other political subdivision. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Public officerï¿½ does not include: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any member of a special district whose official duties do not include the formulation of a budget for the district or the authorization of the expenditure of the districtï¿½s money; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A county health officer appointed pursuant toNRS 439.290. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Public officeï¿½ does not include an office held by: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any member of a special district whose official duties do not include the formulation of a budget for the district or the authorization of the expenditure of the districtï¿½s money; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A county health officer appointed pursuant toNRS 439.290.

section.heading: ï¿½Request for an advisory opinionï¿½ defined.

content.p: Seeking guidance on matters which directly relate to the propriety of his or her own past, present or future conduct as a public officer or employee under the statutory ethical standards set forth in this chapter; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Requesting relief pursuant toNRS 281A.410,281A.430or281A.550.

section.heading: ï¿½Review panelï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Review panelï¿½ means a review panel appointed pursuant toNRS 281A.220.

section.heading: ï¿½State agencyï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½State agencyï¿½ means any agency, bureau, board, commission, department, division, office or other unit of the Executive Department of the State Government.

section.heading: ï¿½State Legislatorï¿½ or ï¿½Legislatorï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½State Legislatorï¿½ or ï¿½Legislatorï¿½ means a member of the Senate or Assembly of the State of Nevada.

section.heading: ï¿½Willful violationï¿½ defined.

content.p: Acted intentionally and knowingly; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Was in a situation where this chapter imposed a duty to act and the public officer or employee intentionally and knowingly failed to act in the manner required by this chapter, ï¿½unless the Commission determines, after applying the factors set forth inNRS 281A.775, that the public officerï¿½s or employeeï¿½s act or failure to act has not resulted in a sanctionable violation of this chapter.

section.heading: Terms ï¿½public officerï¿½ and ï¿½public employeeï¿½ include former public officer or employee; exceptions.

content.p: In applying the provisions of this chapter to an alleged violation by a former public officer or employee, the use of the term ï¿½public officerï¿½ or ï¿½public employeeï¿½ in this chapter must be interpreted to include the former public officer or employee, unless the commencement of proceedings against the former public officer or employee concerning the alleged violation is time-barred by the statute of limitations pursuant toNRS 281A.280.

section.heading: Persons serving in certain positions designated as public officers or employees; applicability.

content.p: Any person who serves in one of the following positions is designated as a public officer solely and exclusively for the purposes of this chapter: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A president of a university, state college or community college within the Nevada System of Higher Education. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A superintendent of a county school district. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A county manager or a city manager. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The provisions of subsection 1 apply to such a person regardless of whether the person serves in the position: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
By appointment, contract or employment; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
With or without compensation; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
On a temporary, interim or acting basis. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person who is not otherwise a public officer is designated as a public officer solely and exclusively for the purposes of this chapter if the person: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is paid compensation with public money; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Serves in a position which involves the exercise of a public power, trust or duty and which ordinarily would be held or filled by a public officer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person who is not otherwise a public employee is designated as a public employee solely and exclusively for the purposes of this chapter if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The person serves in a position which involves the performance of public duties under the substantial and continuing direction and control of a public officer or supervisory public employee; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The position ordinarily would be held or filled by a public employee and would require the public employee to hold a valid professional or occupational license or similar type of authorization issued by a state or local agency to perform the public duties of the position, other than a general business license or similar type of authorization; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The position is entrusted with public duties of a substantial and continuing nature which ordinarily would require a public employee to avoid conflicts between the private interests of the public employee and those of the general public whom the public employee serves; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The person occupies the position on a full-time basis or its equivalent for a substantial and continuing period of time. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The provisions of subsections 3 and 4 must be interpreted and applied to ensure that a person does not evade the provisions of this chapter because a state or local agency elects to use a contractual relationship instead of an employment relationship for a position which ordinarily would be held or filled by a public officer or employee. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If, pursuant to this section, any person is designated as a public officer or employee for the purposes of this chapter, that designation: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Does not make the person a public officer or employee for the purposes of any other law or for any other purposes; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Must not be used, interpreted or applied in any manner to establish, suggest or prove that the person is a public officer or employee for the purposes of any other law or for any other purposes.

section.heading: Abrogation of common-law privileges and immunities; exceptions.

content.p: In any proceeding commenced against a public officer or employee pursuant to the authority of this chapter, including any judicial review thereof, the public officer or employee who is the subject of the proceeding may not assert, claim or raise any common-law privilege or immunity as an affirmative defense, for testimonial or evidentiary purposes or for any other purpose. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The provisions of this chapter are intended to abrogate common-law privileges and immunities only in a proceeding commenced pursuant to the authority of this chapter and only for the public officer or employee who is the subject of the proceeding. This abrogation of common-law privileges and immunities does not apply to or affect: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any privilege or immunity granted by the Constitution of the United States or of the State of Nevada or byNRS 41.071,chapter 49of NRS or any other statute; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any person who is not the subject of the proceeding; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any other proceeding that is not commenced pursuant to the authority of this chapter.

section.heading: Computation of time.

content.p: If the period begins to run on the occurrence of an act or event, the day on which the act or event begins is excluded from the computation. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The last day of the period is included in the computation, except that if the last day falls on a Saturday, Sunday, legal holiday or holiday proclaimed by the Governor or on a day on which the office of the Commission is not open for the conduct of business, the period is extended to the close of business on the next business day.

section.heading: Creation; appointment, terms and qualifications of members; prohibited activities by members; vacancies.

content.p: The Commission on Ethics, consisting of eight members, is hereby created. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Legislative Commission shall appoint to the Commission four residents of the State, at least two of whom must be former public officers or employees, and at least one of whom must be an attorney licensed to practice law in this State. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Governor shall appoint to the Commission four residents of the State, at least two of whom must be former public officers or employees, and at least one of whom must be an attorney licensed to practice law in this State. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Not more than four members of the Commission may be members of the same political party. Not more than four members of the Commission may be residents of the same county. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
None of the members of the Commission may, while the member is serving on the Commission: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Hold another public office; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Be actively involved in the work of any political party or political campaign; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Communicate directly with a State Legislator or a member of a local legislative body on behalf of someone other than himself or herself or the Commission, for compensation, to influence: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The State Legislator with regard to introducing or voting upon any matter or taking other legislative action; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The member of the local legislative body with regard to introducing or voting upon any ordinance or resolution, taking other legislative action or voting upon: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (I) The appropriation of public money; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (II) The issuance of a license or permit; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (III) Any proposed subdivision of land or special exception or variance from zoning regulations. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

After the initial terms, the terms of the members are 4 years. Any vacancy in the membership must be filled by the appropriate appointing authority for the unexpired term. Each member may serve no more than two consecutive full terms.

section.heading: Chair; meetings; compensation; facilities.

content.p: The Commission shall: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
At its first meeting and annually thereafter elect a Chair and Vice Chair from among its members. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Meet regularly at least once in each calendar quarter, unless there are no ethics complaints or requests for advisory opinions pursuant to this chapter, and at other times upon the call of the Chair. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Members of the Commission are entitled to receive a salary of not more than $80 per day, as fixed by the Commission, while engaged in the business of the Commission. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

While engaged in the business of the Commission, each member and employee of the Commission is entitled to receive the per diem allowance and travel expenses provided for state officers and employees generally. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Commission may, within the limits of legislative appropriation, maintain such facilities as are required to carry out its functions.

The Chair shall appoint one or more review panels of three members of the Commission on a rotating basis to perform the functions assigned to such review panels pursuant to this chapter. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Chair and Vice Chair of the Commission may not serve together on a review panel. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Not more than two members of a review panel may be members of the same political party. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a review panel determines that there is just and sufficient cause for the Commission to render an opinion in a matter, the members of the review panel shall not participate in any further proceedings of the Commission relating to that matter.

section.heading: Executive Director: Appointment; qualifications; classification; prohibited activities and other employment.

content.p: The Commission shall appoint, within the limits of legislative appropriation, an Executive Director who shall perform the duties set forth in this chapter and such other duties as may be prescribed by the Commission. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Executive Director must have experience in administration, investigations and law. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Executive Director is in the unclassified service of the State. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Executive Director shall devote the Executive Directorï¿½s entire time and attention to the business of the Commission and shall not pursue any other business or occupation or hold any other office of profit that detracts from the full and timely performance of the Executive Directorï¿½s duties. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Executive Director may not: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Be actively involved in the work of any political party or political campaign; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except in pursuit of the business of the Commission, communicate directly or indirectly with a State Legislator or a member of a local legislative body on behalf of someone other than the Executive Director to influence: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The State Legislator with regard to introducing or voting upon any matter or taking other legislative action; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The member of the local legislative body with regard to introducing or voting upon any ordinance or resolution, taking other legislative action or voting upon: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (I) The appropriation of public money; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (II) The issuance of a license or permit; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (III) Any proposed subdivision of land or special exception or variance from zoning regulations.

section.heading: Executive Director: Duties; employment of staff; designation of qualified person to perform duties when Executive Director unable to act on matter.

content.p: In addition to any other duties imposed upon the Executive Director, the Executive Director shall: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Maintain complete and accurate records of all transactions and proceedings of the Commission. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Receive ethics complaints and requests for advisory opinions pursuant to this chapter. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Gather information and conduct investigations regarding ethics complaints and requests for advisory opinions pursuant to this chapter. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Submit recommendations to the review panel regarding whether there is just and sufficient cause for the Commission to render an opinion in a matter. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Recommend to the Commission any regulations or legislation that the Executive Director considers desirable or necessary to improve the operation of the Commission and maintain high standards of ethical conduct in government. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Upon the request of any public officer or the employer of a public employee, conduct training on the requirements of this chapter, the rules and regulations adopted by the Commission and previous opinions of the Commission. In any such training, the Executive Director shall emphasize that the Executive Director is not a member of the Commission and that only the Commission may issue opinions concerning the application of the statutory ethical standards to any given set of facts and circumstances. The Commission may charge a reasonable fee to cover the costs of training provided by the Executive Director pursuant to this paragraph. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Perform such other duties, not inconsistent with law, as may be required by the Commission. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Executive Director shall, within the limits of legislative appropriation, employ such persons as are necessary to carry out any of the Executive Directorï¿½s duties relating to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The administration of the affairs of the Commission; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The investigation of matters under the jurisdiction of the Commission. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the Executive Director is prohibited from acting on a particular matter or is otherwise unable to act on a particular matter, the Chair of the Commission shall designate a qualified person to perform the duties of the Executive Director with regard to that particular matter.

section.heading: Commission Counsel: Appointment; qualifications; classification; prohibited activities and other employment.

content.p: The Commission shall appoint, within the limits of legislative appropriation, a Commission Counsel who shall perform the duties set forth in this chapter and such other duties as may be prescribed by the Commission. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Commission Counsel must be an attorney who is licensed to practice law in this State. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Commission Counsel is in the unclassified service of the State. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Commission Counsel shall devote the Commission Counselï¿½s entire time and attention to the business of the Commission and shall not pursue any other business or occupation or hold any other office of profit that detracts from the full and timely performance of the Commission Counselï¿½s duties. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Commission Counsel may not: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Be actively involved in the work of any political party or political campaign; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except in pursuit of the business of the Commission, communicate directly or indirectly with a State Legislator or a member of a local legislative body on behalf of someone other than the Commission Counsel to influence: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The State Legislator with regard to introducing or voting upon any matter or taking other legislative action; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The member of the local legislative body with regard to introducing or voting upon any ordinance or resolution, taking other legislative action or voting upon: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (I) The appropriation of public money; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (II) The issuance of a license or permit; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (III) Any proposed subdivision of land or special exception or variance from zoning regulations.

section.heading: Commission Counsel: Duties; legal advice; appointment or employment of other counsel by Commission under certain circumstances.

content.p: The Commission Counsel is the legal adviser to the Commission. For each opinion of the Commission, the Commission Counsel shall prepare, at the direction of the Commission, the appropriate findings of fact and conclusions as to relevant standards and the propriety of particular conduct. The Commission Counsel shall not issue written opinions concerning the applicability of the statutory ethical standards to a given set of facts and circumstances except as directed by the Commission. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Commission may rely upon the legal advice of the Commission Counsel in conducting its daily operations. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the Commission Counsel is prohibited from acting on a particular matter or is otherwise unable to act on a particular matter, the Commission may: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Request that the Attorney General appoint a deputy to act in the place of the Commission Counsel; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Employ outside legal counsel.

section.heading: Discretionary-function immunity for members and employees of Commission.

content.p: For the purposes ofNRS 41.032, the members of the Commission and employees of the Commission shall be deemed to be exercising or performing a discretionary function or duty in taking any action pursuant to the provisions of this chapter.

section.heading: Assessment for administrative costs: Determination; payment by certain cities and counties; use of proceeds; collection.

content.p: Each county whose population is 10,000 or more and each city whose population is 15,000 or more and that is located within such a county shall pay an assessment for the costs incurred by the Commission each biennium in carrying out its functions pursuant to this chapter. The total amount of money to be derived from assessments paid pursuant to this subsection for a biennium must be determined by the Legislature in the legislatively approved budget of the Commission for that biennium. The assessments must be apportioned among each such city and county based on the proportion that the total population of the city or the total population of the unincorporated area of the county bears to the total population of all such cities and the unincorporated areas of all such counties in this State. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

On or before July 1 of each odd-numbered year, the Executive Director shall, in consultation with the Budget Division of the Office of Finance and the Fiscal Analysis Division of the Legislative Counsel Bureau, determine for the next ensuing biennium the amount of the assessments due for each city and county that is required to pay an assessment pursuant to subsection 1. The assessments must be paid to the Commission in semiannual installments that are due on or before August 1 and February 1 of each year of the biennium. The Executive Director shall send out a billing statement to each such city or county which states the amount of the semiannual installment payment due from the city or county. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any money that the Commission receives pursuant to subsection 2: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Must be deposited in the State Treasury, accounted for separately in the State General Fund and credited to the budget account for the Commission; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
May only be used to carry out the provisions of this chapter and only to the extent authorized for expenditure by the Legislature; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Does not revert to the State General Fund at the end of any fiscal year; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Does not revert to a city or county if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The actual expenditures by the Commission are less than the amount of the assessments approved by the Legislature pursuant to subsection 1 and the city or county has already remitted its semiannual installment to the Commission for the billing period; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The budget of the Commission is modified after the amount of the assessments has been approved by the Legislature pursuant to subsection 1 and the city or county has already remitted its semiannual installment to the Commission for the billing period. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If any installment payment is not paid on or before the date on which it is due, the Executive Director shall make reasonable efforts to collect the delinquent payment. If the Executive Director is not able to collect the arrearage, the Executive Director shall submit a claim for the amount of the unpaid installment payment to the Department of Taxation. If the Department of Taxation receives such a claim, the Department shall deduct the amount of the claim from money that would otherwise be allocated from the Local Government Tax Distribution Account to the city or county that owes the installment payment and shall transfer that amount to the Commission. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

As used in this section, ï¿½populationï¿½ means the current population estimate for that city or county as determined and published by the Department of Taxation and the demographer employed pursuant toNRS 360.283.

section.heading: Authority to apply for and accept grants, contributions, services and money.

content.p: The Commission may apply for and accept grants, contributions, services or money for the purposes of carrying out the provisions of this chapter only if the action is approved by a majority vote in an open public meeting of the Commission and the Commission complies with the provisions of the State Budget Act.

section.heading: Jurisdiction; statute of limitations.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in this section, the Commission has jurisdiction to investigate and take appropriate action regarding an alleged violation of this chapter by a public officer or employee or former public officer or employee in any proceeding commenced by an ethics complaint, which is filed with the Commission or initiated by the Commission on its own motion, within 2 years after the alleged violation or reasonable discovery of the alleged violation. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Commission does not have jurisdiction regarding alleged conduct by a public officer or employee or former public officer or employee for which: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A complaint may be filed or, if the applicable limitations period has expired, could have been filed with the United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission or the Nevada Equal Rights Commission; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A complaint or employment-related grievance may be filed or, if the applicable limitations period has expired, could have been filed with another appropriate agency with jurisdiction to redress alleged discrimination or harassment, including, without limitation, a state or local employee-management relations board or similar state or local agency, ï¿½but any bar on the Commissionï¿½s jurisdiction imposed by this subsection applies only to the extent that it pertains to the alleged discrimination or harassment, and this subsection does not deprive the Commission of jurisdiction regarding the alleged conduct if such conduct is sanctionable separately or concurrently under the provisions of this chapter, irrespective of the alleged discrimination or harassment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For the purposes of this section, a proceeding is commenced: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
On the date on which an ethics complaint is filed in the proper form with the Commission in accordance with the regulations of the Commission; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the ethics complaint is initiated by the Commission on its own motion, on the date on which the Commission serves the public officer or employee or former public officer or employee with notice of the ethics complaint in accordance with the regulations of the Commission.

section.heading: Duties of Commission; inclusion of annotations of opinions of Commission in Nevada Revised Statutes.

content.p: Adopt procedural regulations that are necessary and proper to carry out the provisions of this chapter, including, without limitation: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For the withdrawal of an ethics complaint or a request for an advisory opinion by the person who filed the ethics complaint or request; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
To facilitate the prompt rendition of opinions by the Commission; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

For proceedings concerning an ethics complaint, to facilitate written discovery requests submitted pursuant toNRS 281A.750and281A.755and the disclosure of evidence in the manner required by those sections, including, without limitation, the disclosure of evidence obtained by or on behalf of the Executive Director during the course of the investigation that affirmatively and substantively disproves any alleged violation of this chapter that is related to the ethics complaint and has been referred to the Commission for an adjudicatory hearing. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Prescribe, by regulation, forms and procedures for the submission of statements of acknowledgment filed by public officers pursuant toNRS 281A.500, maintain files of such statements and make the statements available for public inspection. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Cause the making of such investigations as are reasonable and necessary for the rendition of its opinions pursuant to this chapter. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Inform the Attorney General or district attorney of all cases of noncompliance with the requirements of this chapter. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Recommend to the Legislature such further legislation as the Commission considers desirable or necessary to promote and maintain high standards of ethical conduct in government. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Publish a manual for the use of public officers and employees that explains the requirements of this chapter. ï¿½The Legislative Counsel shall prepare annotations to this chapter for inclusion in the Nevada Revised Statutes based on the published opinions of the Commission.

section.heading: Oaths; written requests and subpoenas for participation, attendance and production of books and papers; enforcement by court for noncompliance.

content.p: The Chair and Vice Chair of the Commission may administer oaths. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Commission, upon majority vote, may issue a subpoena to compel the attendance of a witness and the production of any books and papers for any hearing before the Commission. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Upon the request of the Executive Director, the Chair or, in the Chairï¿½s absence, the Vice Chair, may issue a subpoena to compel the participation of a potential witness and the production of any books and papers during the course of any investigation. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Upon the request of the Executive Director or the public officer or employee who is the subject of an ethics complaint, the Chair or, in the Chairï¿½s absence, the Vice Chair, may issue a subpoena to compel the attendance of a witness and the production of any books and papers for any hearing before the Commission. A public officer or employee who requests the issuance of a subpoena pursuant to this subsection must serve the subpoena in the manner provided in the Nevada Rules of Civil Procedure for service of subpoenas in a civil action and must pay the costs of such service. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Before issuing a subpoena to a public officer or employee who is the subject of an ethics complaint to compel his or her participation in any investigation, his or her attendance as a witness or his or her production of any books and papers, the Executive Director shall submit a written request to the public officer or employee requesting: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The voluntary attendance of the public officer or employee as a witness; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The voluntary production by the public officer or employee of any books and papers relating to the ethics complaint. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Each written request submitted by the Executive Director pursuant to subsection 5 must specify the time and place for the voluntary participation of the public officer or employee in the investigation, attendance of the public officer or employee as a witness or production of any books and papers, and designate with certainty the books and papers requested, if any. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the public officer or employee fails or refuses to respond to the Executive Directorï¿½s written request pursuant to subsection 5 to voluntarily participate or attend at the time and place specified or produce the books and papers requested by the Executive Director within 5 business days after receipt of the written request, the Chair or, in the Chairï¿½s absence, the Vice Chair, may issue the subpoena. Failure of the public officer or employee to comply with the written request of the Executive Director shall be deemed a waiver by the public officer or employee of the time limits set forth inNRS 281A.700to281A.790, inclusive, that apply to proceedings concerning the ethics complaint. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If any witness fails or refuses to participate, attend, testify or produce any books and papers as required by the subpoena, the Chair or, in the Chairï¿½s absence, the Vice Chair, may report to the district court by petition, setting forth that: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Due notice has been given of the time and place of the participation or attendance of the witness or the production of the books and papers; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The witness has been subpoenaed pursuant to this section; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The witness has failed or refused to participate, attend, testify or produce the books and papers as required by the subpoena, or has failed or refused to answer questions propounded to the witness, ï¿½and asking for an order of the court compelling the witness to participate, attend, testify or produce the books and papers as required by the subpoena. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Upon such a petition, the court shall enter an order directing the witness to appear before the court at a time and place to be fixed by the court in its order, the time to be not more than 10 days after the date of the order, and then and there show cause why the witness has not participated, attended, testified or produced the books or papers as required by the subpoena. A certified copy of the order must be served upon the witness. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If it appears to the court that the subpoena was regularly issued pursuant to this section, the court shall enter an order that the witness comply with the subpoena, at the time and place fixed in the order, and participate, attend, testify or produce the required books and papers. Upon failure to obey the order, the witness must be dealt with as for contempt of court.

section.heading: Establishment; functions; limitations on powers; confidentiality.

content.p: Any state agency or the governing body of a county or an incorporated city may establish a specialized or local ethics committee to complement the functions of the Commission. A specialized or local ethics committee may: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Establish a code of ethical standards suitable for the particular ethical problems encountered in its sphere of activity. The standards may not be less restrictive than the statutory ethical standards. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Render an opinion upon the request of any public officer or employee of its own organization or level seeking an interpretation of its ethical standards on questions directly related to the propriety of the public officerï¿½s or employeeï¿½s own future official conduct or refer the request to the Commission. Any public officer or employee subject to the jurisdiction of the committee shall direct the public officerï¿½s or employeeï¿½s inquiry to that committee instead of the Commission. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Require the filing of financial disclosure statements by public officers on forms prescribed by the committee or the city clerk if the form has been: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Submitted, at least 60 days before its anticipated distribution, to the Secretary of State for review; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Upon review, approved by the Secretary of State. The Secretary of State shall not approve the form unless the form contains all the information required to be included in a financial disclosure statement pursuant toNRS 281.571. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Secretary of State is not responsible for the costs of producing or distributing a form for filing a financial disclosure statement pursuant to the provisions of subsection 1. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A specialized or local ethics committee shall not attempt to interpret or render an opinion regarding the statutory ethical standards. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Each request for an opinion submitted to a specialized or local ethics committee, each hearing held to obtain information on which to base an opinion, all deliberations relating to an opinion, each opinion rendered by a committee and any motion relating to the opinion are confidential unless: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The public officer or employee acts in contravention of the opinion; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The requester discloses the content of the opinion.

section.heading: General requirements; exceptions.

content.p: A public officer or employee shall not seek or accept any gift, service, favor, employment, engagement, emolument or economic opportunity, for the public officer or employee or any person to whom the public officer or employee has a commitment in a private capacity, which would tend improperly to influence a reasonable person in the public officerï¿½s or employeeï¿½s position to depart from the faithful and impartial discharge of the public officerï¿½s or employeeï¿½s public duties. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A public officer or employee shall not use the public officerï¿½s or employeeï¿½s position in government to secure or grant unwarranted privileges, preferences, exemptions or advantages for the public officer or employee, any business entity in which the public officer or employee has a significant pecuniary interest or any person to whom the public officer or employee has a commitment in a private capacity. As used in this subsection, ï¿½unwarrantedï¿½ means without justification or adequate reason. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A public officer or employee shall not participate as an agent of government in the negotiation or execution of a contract between the government and the public officer or employee, any business entity in which the public officer or employee has a significant pecuniary interest or any person to whom the public officer or employee has a commitment in a private capacity. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A public officer or employee shall not accept any salary, retainer, augmentation, expense allowance or other compensation from any private source, for the public officer or employee or any person to whom the public officer or employee has a commitment in a private capacity, for the performance of the public officerï¿½s or employeeï¿½s duties as a public officer or employee. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a public officer or employee acquires, through the public officerï¿½s or employeeï¿½s public duties or relationships, any information which by law or practice is not at the time available to people generally, the public officer or employee shall not use the information to further a significant pecuniary interest of the public officer or employee or any other person or business entity. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A public officer or employee shall not suppress any governmental report or other official document because it might tend to affect unfavorably a significant pecuniary interest of the public officer or employee or any person to whom the public officer or employee has a commitment in a private capacity. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except for State Legislators who are subject to the restrictions set forth in subsection 8, a public officer or employee shall not use governmental time, property, equipment or other facility to benefit a significant personal or pecuniary interest of the public officer or employee or any person to whom the public officer or employee has a commitment in a private capacity. This subsection does not prohibit: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A limited use of governmental property, equipment or other facility for personal purposes if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The public officer or employee who is responsible for and has authority to authorize the use of such property, equipment or other facility has established a policy allowing the use or the use is necessary as a result of emergency circumstances; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The cost or value related to the use is nominal; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The use of mailing lists, computer data or other information lawfully obtained from a governmental agency which is available to members of the general public for nongovernmental purposes; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The use of telephones or other means of communication if there is not a special charge for that use. ï¿½If a governmental agency incurs a cost as a result of a use that is authorized pursuant to this subsection or would ordinarily charge a member of the general public for the use, the public officer or employee shall promptly reimburse the cost or pay the charge to the governmental agency. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A State Legislator shall not: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Use governmental time, property, equipment or other facility for a nongovernmental purpose or for the private benefit of the State Legislator or any other person. This paragraph does not prohibit: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A limited use of state property and resources for personal purposes if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (I) The use does not interfere with the performance of the State Legislatorï¿½s public duties; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (II) The cost or value related to the use is nominal; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (III) The use does not create the appearance of impropriety; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The use of mailing lists, computer data or other information lawfully obtained from a governmental agency which is available to members of the general public for nongovernmental purposes; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The use of telephones or other means of communication if there is not a special charge for that use. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

In unusual and infrequent situations where the employeeï¿½s service is reasonably necessary to permit the State Legislator or legislative employee to perform that personï¿½s official duties; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Where such service has otherwise been established as legislative policy. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A public officer or employee shall not attempt to benefit a significant personal or pecuniary interest of the public officer or employee or any person to whom the public officer or employee has a commitment in a private capacity through the influence of a subordinate. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A public officer or employee shall not seek other employment or contracts for the public officer or employee or any person to whom the public officer or employee has a commitment in a private capacity through the use of the public officerï¿½s or employeeï¿½s official position.

section.heading: Limitations on representing or counseling private persons before public agencies; request for relief from strict application of certain provisions.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided inNRS 678A.360, if a public officer or employee serves in a state agency of the Executive Department or an agency of any county, city or other political subdivision, the public officer or employee: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Shall not accept compensation from any private person to represent or counsel the private person on any issue pending before the agency in which that public officer or employee serves, if the agency makes decisions; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the public officer or employee leaves the service of the agency, shall not, for 1 year after leaving the service of the agency, represent or counsel for compensation a private person upon any issue which was under consideration by the agency during the public officerï¿½s or employeeï¿½s service. As used in this paragraph, ï¿½issueï¿½ includes a case, proceeding, application, contract or determination, but does not include the proposal or consideration of legislative measures or administrative regulations. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except as otherwise provided in subsection 3, a State Legislator or a member of a local legislative body, or a public officer or employee whose public service requires less than half of his or her time, may represent or counsel a private person before an agency in which he or she does not serve. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A member of a local legislative body shall not represent or counsel a private person for compensation before another local agency if the territorial jurisdiction of the other local agency includes any part of the county in which the member serves. The Commission may relieve the member from the strict application of the provisions of this subsection if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The member files a request for an advisory opinion from the Commission pursuant toNRS 281A.675; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Commission determines that such relief is not contrary to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The best interests of the public; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The continued ethical integrity of each local agency affected by the matter; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The provisions of this chapter. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

For the purposes of subsection 3, the request for an advisory opinion, the advisory opinion and all meetings, hearings and proceedings of the Commission in such a matter are governed by the provisions ofNRS 281A.670to281A.690, inclusive. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Unless permitted by this section, a public officer or employee shall not represent or counsel a private person for compensation before any state agency of the Executive or Legislative Department.

section.heading: Requirements regarding disclosure of conflicts of interest and abstention from voting because of certain types of conflicts; effect of abstention on quorum and voting requirements; exceptions.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in this section, a public officer or employee shall not approve, disapprove, vote, abstain from voting or otherwise act upon a matter: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Which would reasonably be affected by the public officerï¿½s or employeeï¿½s commitment in a private capacity to the interests of another person; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Which would reasonably be related to the nature of any representation or counseling that the public officer or employee provided to a private person for compensation before another agency within the immediately preceding year, provided such representation or counseling is permitted byNRS 281A.410, ï¿½without disclosing information concerning the gift or loan, the significant pecuniary interest, the commitment in a private capacity to the interests of the other person or the nature of the representation or counseling of the private person that is sufficient to inform the public of the potential effect of the action or abstention upon the person who provided the gift or loan, upon the public officerï¿½s or employeeï¿½s significant pecuniary interest, upon the person to whom the public officer or employee has a commitment in a private capacity or upon the private person who was represented or counseled by the public officer or employee. Such a disclosure must be made at the time the matter is considered. If the public officer or employee is a member of a body which makes decisions, the public officer or employee shall make the disclosure in public to the chair and other members of the body. If the public officer or employee is not a member of such a body and holds an appointive office, the public officer or employee shall make the disclosure to the supervisory head of the public officerï¿½s or employeeï¿½s organization or, if the public officer holds an elective office, to the general public in the area from which the public officer is elected. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The provisions of subsection 1 do not require a public officer to disclose: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any campaign contributions that the public officer reported in a timely manner pursuant toNRS 294A.120or294A.125; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any contributions to a legal defense fund that the public officer reported in a timely manner pursuant toNRS 294A.286. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except as otherwise provided in this section, in addition to the requirements of subsection 1, a public officer shall not vote upon or advocate the passage or failure of, but may otherwise participate in the consideration of, a matter with respect to which the independence of judgment of a reasonable person in the public officerï¿½s situation would be materially affected by: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The public officerï¿½s significant pecuniary interest; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The public officerï¿½s commitment in a private capacity to the interests of another person. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In interpreting and applying the provisions of subsection 3: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

It must be presumed that the independence of judgment of a reasonable person in the public officerï¿½s situation would not be materially affected by the public officerï¿½s acceptance of a gift or loan, significant pecuniary interest or commitment in a private capacity to the interests of another person where the resulting benefit or detriment accruing to the public officer, or if the public officer has a commitment in a private capacity to the interests of another person, accruing to the other person, is not greater than that accruing to any other member of any general business, profession, occupation or group that is affected by the matter. The presumption set forth in this paragraph does not affect the applicability of the requirements set forth in subsection 1 relating to the duty of the public officer to make a proper disclosure at the time the matter is considered and in the manner required by subsection 1. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Commission must give appropriate weight and proper deference to the public policy of this State which favors the right of a public officer to perform the duties for which the public officer was elected or appointed and to vote or otherwise act upon a matter, provided the public officer makes a proper disclosure at the time the matter is considered and in the manner required by subsection 1. Because abstention by a public officer disrupts the normal course of representative government and deprives the public and the public officerï¿½s constituents of a voice in governmental affairs, the provisions of this section are intended to require abstention only in clear cases where the independence of judgment of a reasonable person in the public officerï¿½s situation would be materially affected by the public officerï¿½s acceptance of a gift or loan, significant pecuniary interest or commitment in a private capacity to the interests of another person. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a public officer declares to the body or committee in which the vote is to be taken that the public officer will abstain from voting because of the requirements of this section, the necessary quorum to act upon and the number of votes necessary to act upon the matter, as fixed by any statute, ordinance or rule, is reduced as though the member abstaining were not a member of the body or committee. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The provisions of this section do not, under any circumstances: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Prohibit a member of a local legislative body from requesting or introducing a legislative measure; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Require a member of a local legislative body to take any particular action before or while requesting or introducing a legislative measure. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The provisions of this section do not, under any circumstances, apply to State Legislators or allow the Commission to exercise jurisdiction or authority over State Legislators. The responsibility of a State Legislator to make disclosures concerning gifts, loans, interests or commitments and the responsibility of a State Legislator to abstain from voting upon or advocating the passage or failure of a matter are governed by the Standing Rules of the Legislative Department of State Government which are adopted, administered and enforced exclusively by the appropriate bodies of the Legislative Department of State Government pursuant toSection 6 of Article 4of the Nevada Constitution. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½public officerï¿½ and ï¿½public employeeï¿½ do not include a State Legislator.

section.heading: Contracts in which public officer or employee has interest prohibited; exceptions; request for relief from strict application of certain provisions.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in this section andNRS 218A.970and332.800, a public officer or employee shall not bid on or enter into a contract between an agency and any business entity in which the public officer or employee has a significant pecuniary interest. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A member of any board, commission or similar body who is engaged in the profession, occupation or business regulated by such board, commission or body may, in the ordinary course of his or her business, bid on or enter into a contract with an agency, except the board, commission or body on which he or she is a member, if the member has not taken part in developing the contract plans or specifications and the member will not be personally involved in opening, considering or accepting offers. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A full- or part-time faculty member or employee of the Nevada System of Higher Education may bid on or enter into a contract with an agency, or may benefit financially or otherwise from a contract between an agency and a private entity, if the contract complies with the policies established by the Board of Regents of the University of Nevada pursuant toNRS 396.255. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, 3 or 5, a public officer or employee may bid on or enter into a contract with an agency if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The contracting process is controlled by the rules of open competitive bidding or the rules of open competitive bidding or for a solicitation are not employed as a result of the applicability ofNRS 332.112or332.148; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The sources of supply are limited; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The public officer or employee has not taken part in developing the contract plans or specifications; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The public officer or employee will not be personally involved in opening, considering or accepting offers. ï¿½If a public officer who is authorized to bid on or enter into a contract with an agency pursuant to this subsection is a member of the governing body of the agency, the public officer, pursuant to the requirements ofNRS 281A.420, shall disclose the public officerï¿½s interest in the contract and shall not vote on or advocate the approval of the contract. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A member of a local legislative body shall not, either individually or through any business entity in which the member has a significant pecuniary interest, sell goods or services to the local agency governed by his or her local legislative body unless: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The member, or the business entity in which the member has a significant pecuniary interest, offers the sole source of supply of the goods or services within the territorial jurisdiction of the local agency governed by his or her local legislative body; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The local legislative body includes in the public notice and agenda for the meeting at which it will consider the purchase of such goods or services a clear and conspicuous statement that it is considering purchasing such goods or services from one of its members, or from a business entity in which the member has a significant pecuniary interest; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

At the meeting, the member discloses his or her significant pecuniary interest in the purchase of such goods or services and does not vote upon or advocate the approval of the matter pursuant to the requirements ofNRS 281A.420; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The local legislative body approves the purchase of such goods or services in accordance with all other applicable provisions of law. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Commission may relieve a public officer or employee from the strict application of the provisions of this section if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The public officer or employee files a request for an advisory opinion from the Commission pursuant toNRS 281A.675; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Commission determines that such relief is not contrary to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The best interests of the public; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The continued ethical integrity of each agency affected by the matter; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The provisions of this chapter. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

For the purposes of subsection 6, the request for an advisory opinion, the advisory opinion and all meetings, hearings and proceedings of the Commission in such a matter are governed by the provisions ofNRS 281A.670to281A.690, inclusive.

On or before the date on which a public officer swears or affirms the oath of office, the public officer must be informed of the statutory ethical standards and the duty to file an acknowledgment of the statutory ethical standards in accordance with this section by: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For an appointed public officer, the appointing authority of the public officer; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For an elected public officer of: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The city, the city clerk; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Legislative Department of the State Government, the Director of the Legislative Counsel Bureau; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Executive Department of the State Government, the Director of the Department of Administration, or his or her designee. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Within 30 days after a public employee begins employment: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Director of the Department of Administration, or his or her designee, shall provide each new public employee of a state agency with the information prepared by the Commission concerning the statutory ethical standards; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The manager of each local agency, or his or her designee, shall provide each new public employee of the local agency with the information prepared by the Commission concerning the statutory ethical standards. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Each public officer shall acknowledge that the public officer: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has received, read and understands the statutory ethical standards; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has a responsibility to inform himself or herself of any amendments to the statutory ethical standards as soon as reasonably practicable after each session of the Legislature. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The acknowledgment must be executed on a form prescribed by the Commission and must be filed with the Commission: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the public officer is elected to office at the general election, on or before January 15 of the year following the public officerï¿½s election. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the public officer is elected to office at an election other than the general election or is appointed to office, on or before the 30th day following the date on which the public officer swears or affirms the oath of office. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, a public officer shall execute and file the acknowledgment once for each term of office. If the public officer serves at the pleasure of the appointing authority and does not have a definite term of office, the public officer, in addition to executing and filing the acknowledgment after the public officer swears or affirms the oath of office in accordance with subsection 4, shall execute and file the acknowledgment on or before January 15 of each even-numbered year while the public officer holds that office. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For the purposes of this section, the acknowledgment is timely filed if, on or before the last day for filing, the acknowledgment is filed in one of the following ways: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Delivered in person to the principal office of the Commission in Carson City. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Mailed to the Commission by first-class mail, or other class of mail that is at least as expeditious, postage prepaid. Filing by mail is complete upon timely depositing the acknowledgment with the United States Postal Service. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Dispatched to a third-party commercial carrier for delivery to the Commission within 3 calendar days. Filing by third-party commercial carrier is complete upon timely depositing the acknowledgment with the third-party commercial carrier. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Transmitted to the Commission by facsimile machine or other electronic means authorized by the Commission. Filing by facsimile machine or other electronic means is complete upon receipt of the transmission by the Commission. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a public officer is serving in a public office and executes and files the acknowledgment for that office as required by the applicable provisions of this section, the public officer shall be deemed to have satisfied the requirements of this section for any other office held concurrently by him or her. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The form for making the acknowledgment must contain: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The address of the Internet website of the Commission where a public officer may view the statutory ethical standards and print a copy of the standards; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The telephone number and mailing address of the Commission where a public officer may make a request to obtain a printed copy of the statutory ethical standards from the Commission. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Whenever the Commission, or any public officer or employee as part of the public officerï¿½s or employeeï¿½s official duties, provides a public officer with a printed copy of the form for making the acknowledgment, a printed copy of the statutory ethical standards must be included with the form. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Commission shall retain each acknowledgment filed pursuant to this section for 6 years after the date on which the acknowledgment was filed. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Willful refusal to execute and file the acknowledgment required by this section shall be deemed to be: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A willful violation of this chapter for the purposes ofNRS 281A.785and281A.790; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Nonfeasance in office for the purposes ofNRS 283.440and, if the public officer is removable from office pursuant toNRS 283.440, the Commission may file a complaint in the appropriate court for removal of the public officer pursuant to that section. This paragraph grants an exclusive right to the Commission, and no other person may file a complaint against the public officer pursuant toNRS 283.440based on any violation of this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½general electionï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 293.060.

section.heading: Public officer or employee prohibited from accepting or receiving honorarium; penalty.

content.p: A public officer or public employee shall not accept or receive an honorarium. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An honorarium paid on behalf of a public officer or public employee to a charitable organization from which the officer or employee does not derive any financial benefit is deemed not to be accepted or received by the officer or employee for the purposes of this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
This section does not prohibit: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The receipt of payment for work performed outside the normal course of a personï¿½s public office or employment if the performance of that work is consistent with the applicable policies of the personï¿½s public employer regarding supplemental employment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The receipt of an honorarium by the spouse of a public officer or public employee if it is related to the spouseï¿½s profession or occupation. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

As used in this section, ï¿½honorariumï¿½ means the payment of money or anything of value for an appearance or speech by the public officer or public employee in the officerï¿½s or employeeï¿½s capacity as a public officer or public employee. The term does not include the payment of: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The actual and necessary costs incurred by the public officer or public employee, the officerï¿½s or employeeï¿½s spouse or the officerï¿½s or employeeï¿½s aid for transportation and for lodging and meals while the public officer or public employee is away from the officerï¿½s or employeeï¿½s residence. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Compensation which would otherwise have been earned by the public officer or public employee in the normal course of the officerï¿½s or employeeï¿½s public office or employment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A fee for a speech related to the officerï¿½s or employeeï¿½s profession or occupation outside of the officerï¿½s or employeeï¿½s public office or employment if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Other members of the profession or occupation are ordinarily compensated for such a speech; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The fee paid to the public officer or public employee is approximately the same as the fee that would be paid to a member of the private sector whose qualifications are similar to those of the officer or employee for a comparable speech. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A fee for a speech delivered to an organization of legislatures, legislators or other elected officers. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In addition to any other penalties provided by law, a public officer or public employee who violates the provisions of this section shall forfeit the amount of the honorarium.

section.heading: Public officer or employee prohibited from requesting or otherwise causing governmental entity to incur expense or make expenditure to support or oppose ballot question or candidate in certain circumstances.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsections 4 and 5, a public officer or employee shall not request or otherwise cause a governmental entity to incur an expense or make an expenditure to support or oppose: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A ballot question. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A candidate. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For the purposes of paragraph
of subsection 1, an expense incurred or an expenditure made by a governmental entity shall be considered an expense incurred or an expenditure made in support of a candidate if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The expense is incurred or the expenditure is made for the creation or dissemination of a pamphlet, brochure, publication, advertisement or television programming that prominently features the activities of a current public officer of the governmental entity who is a candidate for a state, local or federal elective office; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The pamphlet, brochure, publication, advertisement or television programming described in paragraph
is created or disseminated during the period specified in subsection 3. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The period during which the provisions of subsection 2 apply to a particular governmental entity begins when a current public officer of that governmental entity files a declaration of candidacy and ends on the date of the general election, general city election or special election for the office for which the current public officer of the governmental entity is a candidate. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The provisions of this section do not prohibit the creation or dissemination of, or the appearance of a candidate in or on, as applicable, a pamphlet, brochure, publication, advertisement or television programming that: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is made available to the public on a regular basis and merely describes the functions of: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The public office held by the public officer who is the candidate; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The governmental entity by which the public officer who is the candidate is employed; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is created or disseminated in the course of carrying out a duty of: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The public officer who is the candidate; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The governmental entity by which the public officer who is the candidate is employed. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The provisions of this section do not prohibit an expense or an expenditure incurred to create or disseminate a television program that provides a forum for discussion or debate regarding a ballot question, if persons both in support of and in opposition to the ballot question participate in the television program. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Governmental entityï¿½ means: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The government of this State; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An agency of a political subdivision of this State. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Pamphlet, brochure, publication, advertisement or television programmingï¿½ includes, without limitation, a publication, a public service announcement and any programming on a television station created to provide community access to cable television. The term does not include: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A press release issued to the media by a governmental entity; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The official website of a governmental entity.

section.heading: Governmental grant, contract or lease and certain actions taken in violation of chapter are voidable; prohibited contract is void; recovery of benefit received as result of violation.

content.p: In addition to any other penalties provided by law, a governmental grant, contract or lease entered into in violation of this chapter is voidable by the State, county, city or political subdivision. In a determination under this section of whether to void a grant, contract or lease, the interests of innocent third parties who could be damaged must be taken into account. The Attorney General, district attorney or city attorney must give notice of the intent to void a grant, contract or lease under this section no later than 30 days after the Commission has determined that there has been a related violation of this chapter. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In addition to any other penalties provided by law, a contract prohibited byNRS 281.230which is knowingly entered into by a person designated in subsection 1 ofNRS 281.230is void. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any action taken by the State in violation of this chapter is voidable, except that the interests of innocent third parties in the nature of the violation must be taken into account. The Attorney General may also pursue any other available legal or equitable remedies. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

In addition to any other penalties provided by law, the Attorney General may recover any fee, compensation, gift or benefit received by a person as a result of a violation of this chapter by a public officer. An action to recover pursuant to this section must be brought within 2 years after the violation or reasonable discovery of the violation.

section.heading: Employment of certain former public officers and employees by regulated businesses prohibited; certain former public officers and employees prohibited from soliciting or accepting employment from certain persons contracting with State or local government; request for relief from strict application of certain provisions.

content.p: A former member of the Public Utilities Commission of Nevada shall not: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Be employed by a public utility or parent organization or subsidiary of a public utility; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Appear before the Public Utilities Commission of Nevada to testify on behalf of a public utility or parent organization or subsidiary of a public utility, ï¿½for 1 year after the termination of the memberï¿½s service on the Public Utilities Commission of Nevada. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A former member of the Nevada Gaming Control Board or the Nevada Gaming Commission shall not: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Appear before the Nevada Gaming Control Board or the Nevada Gaming Commission on behalf of a person who holds a license issued pursuant tochapter 463or464of NRS or who is required to register with the Nevada Gaming Commission pursuant tochapter 463of NRS; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
